content.title: We don’t want Emma: Shorten - The Australian
content.desc: Bill Shorten says he does not want controversial Labor MP Emma Husar to run for the Labor Party in Lindsay. Ms Husar stood aside as the party’s candidate in her marginal Western Sydney seat after she was hit with bullying and sexual harassment allegations. But she has since claimed she was defamed and wants to run for re-election. However the Opposition Leader said today he still believes that Ms Husar stepping aside as the party’s candidate is the “best thing.” “I said at the time when Emma wrote saying she wasn’t going to recontest the election, that that was the right decision then for h...

content.title: Emma Husar disendorsed by Labor - ABC News
content.desc: By Nick Dole The New South Wales Labor party has formally withdrawn its endorsement of western Sydney MP Emma Husar. The party's administrative committee met today and decided to refer preselection in the seat of Lindsay to the party's national executive. It paves the way for former NSW minister Diane Beamer to represent Labor at the next federal election. Ms Husar has not ruled out a legal challenge or running as an independent.

content.title: Federal MP launches defamation proceedings, arguing her career has been ruined - ABC News
content.desc: Embattled Labor MP Emma Husar has launched defamation proceedings against Buzzfeed, claiming reporting of false allegations of misconduct and harassment has ruined her career. Key points: - Emma Husar is taking legal action against Buzzfeed and journalist Alice Workman - She claims the reporting of false allegations of misconduct and harassment have ruined her career - Having initially planned to retire from politics, she is considering legal action to force Labor to keep her as its candidate Ms Husar has vowed to fight for her position as Labor's candidate for the marginal western Sydney e...
